text: REVEAL TORTUGA -- cartel henchman-turned-DEA-snitch from Episode 207 -- puffing on the cigar as it gets lit. We kn we‘re in flashback because his head is attached. He sits the thick, wooden bar of a seedy Mexican CANTINA, wearing caballero hat and boots. A barkeep (BETO, male, younger t Tortuga) stands behind the bar holding the lighter. We are at a dark watering hole in a one-horse border-town rural Juarez -- a place where campesinos, town drunks, an unemployed youths come to escape the blistering heat and medicate themselves into oblivion. No chicas in this join Dingy, rustic, with Spanish-style Western character (arch and stucco walls would be great). Lines of liquor bottles behind the bar (maybe shelved in front of plate mirrors) reflect dim overhead lights and a few neon cervezas signs back KITCHEN (or pantry) abuts the main barroom, separate a swinging door. TWO work-weary LABORERS (character faces: more rural Maya than bullet-headed toughs) drink cervezas at the bar a fe seats down from Tortuga. (CONTINUED)
BREAKING BAD #303 "I.F.T." Writer's Draft 8/26/09 2.

FIVE or SIX other PATRONS sit at roughly-hewn wood tables staring with disinterest at a futbol match playing on an older model TV over the bar. Just killing time. A lot, judging from the clutter of empty long-necks lined up lik casualties on the tables. Beto finishes lighting Tortuga’s cigar. Slides him a beer Then pours him a brimming tumbler of tequila. Tortuga dow it in one throw-back. TAP-TAPS! his glass hard on the bar {All dialogue in Teaser is in SPANISH, subtitled in Engli

More. Whoa. Beto’s served Tortuga a few times prior, and he’s g a strong hunch Tortuga is el cartel. Thus, his banter is amiable with no mind to affront. That said, Tortuga’s got treacherous, make-or-break deal going down in a couple of hours; he’s even surlier than usual.
(friendly, just kidding) Careful, sefor. Hot day like today, too much oil in the machine can cause it to blow a gasket.

(beat, scoffs) There are two kinds of men in the world. Those who drink, and those who pour. (stares coldly) Shut up and fill my glass. Uh-oh. A dead silence cuts across the bar. The laborers shift nervously on their stools, sensing trouble. Beto refills the tumbler with a shaky hand. Tortuga fishes for a GOLD MONEY CLIP with a THICK wad of pesos and dollars. As he plucks out bills to pay for his drinks, the laborers can’t help but glance at his copious cash. Tortuga notices their envy. Indeed, he relishes it.

Hey, you two. (off patrons: us? gulp!) Yeah, you. My Mayan brothers. You know, I used to be just like you? Good, honest campesinos. Worked dirt for the man til my hands bled. (snorts, waves bankroll) The way you just looked at me... (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
BREAKING BAD #303 "I.F.T." Writer's Draft 8/26/09 3.

I had that same stupid look on my mug whenever I saw a rich man flash his bank. No more. Wanna know why? No. They really don’t. But God forbid they show disrespec They swallow nervously. Timidly nod their heads.
Si, sefior. Tortuga makes them wait for it, while he gulps down his second tequila. Ahhh! Grits his teeth against the burn.

I learned that a man can never drink his fill by waiting in line for the tap. Tortuga raises his beer. The laborers share a confused lo before lifting their own in response. As Tortuga tilts th bottle...

Bravo, Tortuga. All other heads TURN toward a MEXICAN MAN, who stands in bright sunlight streaming through the now open barroom do (if there are plate mirrors behind the bar, maybe we do a cool mirror reveal for this). This is JUAN BOLSA, avuncular, a little paunchy, in his l 50s or 60s. Wearing loose, tropical cotton garments, perh a Panama hat, he may have been a Mexico city bureaucrat before he turned a dark corner. From a more refined socia stratum than gruff Tortuga, or so he prefers to convey. A cartel underboss, Bolsa is higher up in our fictional car than Tortuga, but not one of the controlling capos. He doesn’t look particularly threatening. Tortuga turns, surprised to see his boss.
Heyy, howya doin‘, boss!? Tortuga stands, shakes Bolsa’‘s outstretched hand.
Good to see you, my friend. You know, I never pegged you for such a deep thinker. Tortuga shrugs it off -- ah, it’s nothing. (CONTINUED )
BREAKING BAD #303 “I.F.T." Writer's Draft 8/26/09 4.

I got a lot of thoughts about a lot of things, boss. There’s no time or place for them all. Bolsa slides into a bar stool. Tortuga follows his boss’ cue, his cocky air now replaced by respectful deference. Tortuga motions to Beto who pours them both tequilas.
So, what brings you way out here to this burro’s asshole of a town?
I knew I would find you here. Tortuga’s eyes widen a notch. Bolsa checks his watch.
Don’t you have a shipment to deliver in a couple of hours? Cutting it close, aren’t you?
Ahhh, lots of time. Tortuga may be slow out the gate, but he always--
(overlapping him) --finishes first. Yes, I know, just like your namesake. I like the way you talk, Tortuga.
Yeah?

Yeah. You’ve got such a way with words. They just roll off your tongue. I like that about you. Bosla raises his glass in toast. Tortuga CLINKS it. They throw back. Bolsa shoots Tortuga a look of apology.
I missed your birthday last month. (off Tortuga, so what?) No, I feel terrible. So bad I came all the way here... to this ‘burro’‘s asshole’... to bring you my present. (CONTINUED)
BREAKING BAD #303 “I.F.T." Writer's Draft 8/26/09 5.
Present? Ahh, come on, boss. No need to go through the trouble.

Forget it, I wanted to. I have it for you in the kitchen. Bolsa nods toward the kitchen. Tortuga peers over. The do is shut. Looks quiet. Foreboding. Like a good place for a ambush. Tortuga doesn’t like the smell of this. Not at al
Back there?

Yes. Come. Follow me. Bolsa stands, motions for Tortuga as he paces toward the kitchen. Tortuga hesitates. Oh, shit! If he splits now, Bolsa will know for certain he’s got something to hide (i he’s a snitch) and then he’s a goner for sure. Reluctantl he rises, follows Bolsa through the swinging door, into..

A grimy, unkempt kitchen. Tortuga, expecting to be jumped cautiously files in behind Bolsa. To his relief, however, finds the kitchen totally empty -~ PHEW! -- except for... A very large, familiar TORTOISE crawling across the floor It was a present after all! Tortuga explodes in a burst o relieved laughter. AH-HA-HA-HA-HA!...
It's perfect!
You really like it?
I love it! What a great pet it will make. Thank you, boss!

Excellent. Let me sign it for you. Bolsa picks up a small CAN of WHITE PAINT and a PAINTBRUS from a nearby counter. Squats, begins to paint some lette with the brush across the animal's shell. Bolsa’s back shields Tortuga’s (and our) view of what he’s spelling ou (CONTINUED )
BREAKING BAD #303 "I.F.T." Writer's Draft 8/26/09 6.

Sign it ‘for the big talker’. Huh? Bolsa finishes painting. He stands and steps aside, REVEALING... “H-O-L-A_D-E-A". Tortuga freezes. Oh, FUCK! -- HE KNOWS!! [Note: This lettering should match what we saw in Episode exactly, as we realize what we're witnessing is the run-u a scene we've previously seen]. The door to the kitchen SWINGS OPEN. In file THE COUSINS! They pace toward Tortuga, eyes on their quarry. One Cousi grabs a large BUTCHER‘’S KNIFE from the counter. ON TORTUGA, paralyzed with fear at the sight of these wei silent killers, approaching like terrifying forces of Nature. Or, more precisely, of Death. His hands shaking, Tortuga fumbles under his shirt for hi gun. But it’s too late. Before he can get a handle on his weapon, the Cousins grab his arms (Juan Bolsa merely watches). Tortuga writhes and struggles to free himself.

No..! No..! But it’s no use. They hold him down. Wrench his head back by the hair, exposing his neck like a lamb at the slaught As the knife-wielding Cousin presses the blade to Tortuga throat, arm cocked and ready to saw off his head, we cut

Tortuga’s ear-piercing scream shatters the silence. The bar patrons lower their heads in terror. Like docile, beaten-down mules, too scared even to move. Their wide, vacant eyes glued to their drinks. Tortuga’s scream reaches an almost inhuman pitch, before truncated by an odd gurgling sound, and then STOPS.
BREAKING BAD #303 “I.F.T.“ Writer's Draft 8/26/09 7.

TIGHT ON a dried up PIZZA. Half out of its box and smeare on the roof. This is the pizza Walt hurled at the end of Episode 302. If we look carefully, we might see way in th b.g. MIKE'S BROWN CHRYSLER parked down the street. A LADDER swings into frame -- CLUNK! -- slams against the edge of the roof. A pair of bright-yellow RUBBER-GLOVED HANDS (first one, then the other) grabs onto the top rung WALT’S head pokes up into frame. His eyes shift to and fr assessing the mess. Shakes his head -- what the hell was thinking? He fishes into his back pocket, pulls out a scrunched up plastic TRASH BAG. Flaps it around, airing i open. Peels the pizza off the roof, shoves it into the ba He takes a damp CLOTH from his other back pocket, scrubs cheesy residue off the shingles. As he stops to pluck off PEPPERONI slice that has petrified to the roof, we cut to
MIKE, in his car, spies Walt, while he talks into his CEL PHONE to Gus’s minion, Victor (whom we do not see or hear

(into phone while spying) Yeah, he’s breathin’, alright. By the looks of him, he’s got no idea how close he came. (beat) I‘m assuming Saul Goodman doesn’t need to know. (beat) Mum, it is. Mike hangs up. Starts the car, pulls away from the curb. Makes a U-turn to avoid passing by the White house. As Mike's sedan drives off, we:

INT. SKYLER’S JEEP - DRIVING - DAY SKYLER drives, while baby HOLLY sits quietly in the car s behind her. She sings along to the mind-numbing BABY MUSI playing on the car stereo (though she’s not into it): (CONTINUED )
BREAKING BAD #303 "I.F.T." Writer's Draft 8/26/09 8.
The wheels on the bus go round and round, round and round, round and round... As Skyler nears the White house, she fumes at the sight o Walt‘s Aztek parked in the driveway. What?! He's back..?!
Skyler shuts off the music. Pulls into the driveway behin the Aztek (but leaves the engine idling). Rifles through BABY-BAG for her cell phone and dials Walt:
Walt? Are you in the house?
SKYLER’S POV: A hand pulls the curtain of the front windo aside, revealing Walt's face. Cell phone to his ear, he speaks to Skyler as he peers at her through the window.
(filtered, almost chipper) Oh, hi. Yep... it’s me. I’m back.
(beat, vexed) No, you‘re not, Walt. Get out of the house.
(calm, simply explaining) It’s my house, too, Skyler. I’m staying. For good.
We had an agreement.
I didn’t agree to anything. (beat) Look, come on inside. We'll talk this through.
--No. There’s nothing to talk about. I’m not coming in until you get... OUT.
(long beat, shrugs) Suit yourself. (CONTINUED)
BREAKING BAD #303 "I.F.T." Writer's Draft 8/26/09 9.

Walt vanishes back behind the curtain. Skyler, bewildered hangs up. Stares in disbelief out the windshield at the Aztek. Last night was frisbee pizza, now breaking and entering? Her anger mounts, until she’s nearly trembling. Then, little Holly, cueing off her mom's anxiety, starts stir and fuss -- weh-weh!...weh! -- in back. Skyler glanc over her shoulder. Ugh! Not going to win this standoff wi a restless baby in the car. In utter frustration, she shu off the car. As she shoves the door open, we cut to:

Skyler barges through the front door, holding the car sea with Holly strapped in. She spots Walt at the dining room table, casually grading exams as if nothing is awry. She sets the car seat down on the living room floor (Holl awake but, of course, now quiet). Storms toward Walt.
Walt looks up, sees her charging. Puts his pen down, sits straight, and waits with his hands clasped on the table. Like Lord Nelson under fire, a picture of calm.
What is wrong with you?! You're trespassing! How did you even... I changed the locks!
(beat, calmly explaining) Skyler, I have every right to be here.
No, you do not. You don’t live here any more. We are getting a divorce.
I don’t agree to a divorce.
It’s not up to you! (beat, “ok, that’s it”) If you don’t get out right now, I will call the police and I will tell them everything. (a beat) I mean it, Walt! (CONTINUED )
BREAKING BAD #303 "I.F.T." Writer's Draft 8/26/09 10.
A long beat. Walt shrugs. Nods toward the phone.

Go ahead. There’s the phone. Skyler cocks her head. Oh, you think I'm kidding? She gra a phone book off the counter, rapidly fans through the pa until she finds the number for the police. Snatches up th phone and dials. Eyes fixed on Walt, she waits for the ca to go through. Then, with demonstrative aplomb, flips the receiver around and holds it out, ear piece towards Walt.

(don’t fuck with me) It's ringing. But Walt is serious, too. He’1ll either live in this hous or go to prison. There is no third way. Through the out- turned receiver, we faintly can hear the operator answer.
(filtered) Albuquerque police department. Beat. Skyler huffs. Rights the receiver and talks into it
I want to report a disturbance, please. (beat) No, it’s not... not exactly a... It's a domestic issue. (beat, then to Walt) They’re connecting me. Right hand to God, I will tell them.

(total resignation) Do what you have to do, Skyler. This family is everything to me. Without it I got nothing to lose. Walt’s total lack of fear in the face of her threat, his Buddha-like acceptance of whatever may happen, only stoke her anger. Is he not taking her seriously?
Fine. (beat, into receiver) Yes, officer. My name is Skyler White. I need police assistance at my home right away. (beat) (MORE ) (CONTINUED )
BREAKING BAD #303 "I.F.T." Writer's Draft 8/26/09 ll.

My soon to be ex-husband broke into my house. I-I need an officer to come and remove him. (beat) It’s Thirty-Eight Twenty-Eight Negra Arroyo Lane. (longer beat) Okay... okay. Thank you. Skyler hangs up. Finger raised, lays down the law.

They‘re coming. If you do not get out of here right now, you are going to jail. And it’s all gonna be on you. Beat. Walt goes back to grading his papers. Skyler continues to stare at him. Who is this man? Has he lost a fear for the law? Square-jawed and determined to find out she turns and... and now what..? Arms crossed, Skyler wanders into the living room, sits d on the couch, and... she waits. Ugh! Stewing in excruciating silence. ANGLE ON the LIVING ROOM CLOCK. Seconds slowly tick-tick- ticking away “High-Noon” style, as Skyler’s moment of tru when she makes good on her threat to tell the police on W or not -- gets closer. And closer. And closer. A grueling nerve-wracking, tediously slow burn... , we hear O.S. the sound of an APPROACHING CAR! Sie leaps up off the couch. Nearly runs to the front door... But right before she gets there, it SWINGS OPEN.. An upbeat WALTER, JR. clunks in. Just in time for the fireworks. Perfect! Skyler frowns. She’s not mad at her son ~- but he’s the last complication she wants to deal w right now. In contrast, Walter, Jr. (having seen the Azte outside) is upbeat, thrilled by the prospect of seeing hi father, whom he spots across the room. Upbeat: WALTER JR. Dad’s here.
Why are you home so early? WALTER, JR. I‘m not. Skyler glances at the clock -- terrific. Walt emerges fro the dining room. (CONTINUED)
BREAKING BAD #303 "I.F.T." Writer's Draft 8/26/09 12.
Hey, son. WALTER, JR. (eyes light up) Dad, you're back..! For good? Walt shrugs -- let's hope so.
(evading) Hey, I’m starving. You want a grilled cheese? WALTER, JR. Ah... sure. I guess. Walt crosses to the kitchen. On the way, he asks Skyler..
Want one, , too? Skyler glowers in reply. She turns to Walter, Jr.

Walter, your father and I have something to discuss. It's private. (beat, do as I say) I‘ll bring your sandwich to your room when it’s ready. WALTER, JR. Mom, I haven't seen Dad in, like... forever. Walter, Jr. turns his back on her, heads to the kitchen.

Walter..? Walter, Jr.'s fed up being kept in the dark. And he's genuinely glad to see his dad. In his teenager’s mind, ho could this not be a step in the right direction, even if mom’s not yet on board? Off Skyler’s isolation:

CLOSE ON a PIECE OF TOASTED BREAD, with greasy melting ch on top, frying in a PAN. We watch as another piece of toa is laid DOWN on top of it, then pressed with a spatula. Cheese goops out the sides and sizzles. (CONTINUED)
BREAKING BAD #303 "I.F.T." Writer's Draft 8/26/09 13.

PULL BACK to reveal Walt, standing over the stove, workin the spatula. Walter, Jr. leans against the counter nearby As father and son chat, Skyler (visible in the b.g.) pace front of the living room window. Baby Holly is asleep nea her, now in a bassinet. Though Walter, Jr.‘s arrival is highly unfortunate, she hasn‘t lost her resolve. But man, those cops are taking their sweet time! WALTER, JR. You gonna be at work tomorrow?
That‘s the plan. WALTER, JR. Good. Cause everyone's saying that sub they got for you really sucks.
Everyone, wow. Well, don’t believe everything you hear. But... it’s good to be missed. Finally, we hear 0.S., DING-DONG! In the b.g., anxious Skyler rushes toward the door.
Skyler opens to reveal two APD PATROLMEN, a SENIOR OFFICE (40s, male) and a ROOKIE OFFICER (younger, male or female
Hello, ma‘am. Are you the one who called the police?

Yes, that was me. Just then, Walter, Jr. walks into the foyer area behind Skyler. A look of shock comes over him. WALTER, JR. You called the cops on Dad? What the hell‘s WRONG with you?! OFF Skyler, mortified, we...
BREAKING BAD #303 "I.F.T." Writer's Draft 8/26/09 14.

Skyler stands with the Senior Officer. Per police protoco the cops have separated the spouses. We can see in the b. Walt being questioned by the Rookie Officer in the dining room. Walter Jr. sits on a bar stool on the dining room s of the breakfast bar -- confused, silent, scared. Skyler is nervous, even more anxious now that Walt has ca her bluff and she is being put to the task. The Senior Officer, on the other hand, has responded to dozens of domestic calls in his career, and he’s got certain preliminary questions he must ask as a matter of procedur He jots down occasional notes on a pad.
I-I came home from work and he was back. Just moved back in. I asked him to leave, but he won't listen. I, ah... I just want him out. I want him out of the house.
(polite) Okay, Mrs. White. There's a couple questions I need to ask you right off the bat. It’s very important that you answer them honestly. (beat) Did he strike you?
No.
Has he ever hit you?

(frustration mounting) No. This is not about violence. This is about trespassing. About him being here against my will. The cop has heard “no violence” before, only to be called back later when the wife is beaten to a pulp. He turns, checks to make sure Walt’s not eyeballing her into silenc from afar. But Walt appears to be cooperating, fully enga with the rookie cop. Does not even appear agitated at all
Okay. Trespassing. You‘re divorced, then? (CONTINUED)
BREAKING BAD #303 "“I.F.T." Writer's Draft 8/26/09 15.
No, working on it. Right now, we're separated.
(I can work with that) Legally separated. As he starts to make a note in his pad...
Well... there’s no court order, if that’s what you mean. But we've been living apart for-for... almost two weeks. Give or take. The cop looks up from his pad. So much for cut and dry.
Look, I changed the locks. Isn't that breaking and entering?
Whose name is on the title to the house?
Both of us are. It's, ah, jointly owned.

We can’t arrest a man for breaking into his own house. Not without an order from the court requiring him to stay away from the premises. (beat, tries again) Unless he‘s threatened you or the kids in any way?

(frustrated, but can’t pull the trigger) No. Not physically. But having him in the house is... it’s not... it’s just not a good thing. WEH-WEH-WEEEEEEEAAAAAHHH!! -- baby Holly stops Skyler mid sentence with a startling, screeching CRY. And what a cry One of those “my-child-is-possessed-by-a-demon” shrieks o anger and injustice and hunger. Skyler’s head swivels tow the sound. The Senior Officer turns, too, as we:  BREAKING BAD #303 "I.F.T." Writer's Draft 8/26/09 16.
SKYLER'S/SENIOR OFFICER'S POV: Walt rushes from the dinin room to Holly. Lifts her from the bassinet. Gently bounce her in his arms, soothing her.

Shhhhhh. It's okay, baby. Holly’s fussiness starts to ease. Walt flashes Skyler a kindly look from the living room - I got it, no problem. Walt picks up a half-full bottle of formula from inside t bassinet. He feeds it to Holly while he paces back to the rookie cop (who now stands at the threshold of the living room). Like a perfect, even-tempered, responsible father.
Sorry about that. Where were we?
(checks notes) Disagreements.

Right. Yes, we've been having... a few problems. She‘’s not in the wrong. I’ve not been the most attentive husband, lately. I’ve been... a little distant. Cold. As Walt bores the rookie cop to tears, he doesn’t look so unattentive. In fact, as he deftly feeds the baby, Walt appears more like a dutiful (if not whipped) house-husban
The Senior Officer turns back to Skyler, now off her game plan, watching Walt feed the baby. Regains her attention:
Mrs. White. Would this be easier if we stepped outside for a minute?

Um... no. I’m-I‘m fine right here. To the officer, this call is looking like a nonviolent (albeit heated) marital disagreement, the cops called in up the ante. It happens. But he’s covered too many ill- fated domestics to not be wary. And he senses Skyler is holding something back. He wants to give her every opportunity to say something that might give him authorit kick Walt out. (CONTINUED)
BREAKING BAD #303 "I.F.T." Writer's Draft 8/26/09 17.

I’m gonna level with you, Mrs. White. If you want your husband out of the house, you gotta help me out. If he’s broken any laws that you know of, anything at all, you should tell me that. (long beat, encouraging) Even if you just got a suspicion of some wrongdoing, I'll work it out. I‘ll get him out of here for you. And there it is -- the “law” practically begging her to m good on her threat. Skyler exhales deeply. Digs to regain her mettle, as she locks eyes with Walt across the room. So nauseatingly Gan like and passive. She's sick of his smug manipulations an bullshit, his imprisonment of her. She warned him. To hel with him! Skyker looks at the cop in front of her. Then, just as she’s about to turn Walt in:

What’s your take on all this, young man? SKYLER‘S POV: From across the living room, Skyler glimpse the Rookie Officer now questioning her son. WALTER, JR. (distraught) It’s my Mom’s fault! She won’t say what my dad did because he didn’t do anything. She’s nuts! My Dad, he’s a great guy. Skyler stops herself. She wants so badly to vindicate herself, scream out the truth. But she just can’t do it. A long beat, as the officer reads her. Finally, he conclu she’s got nothing to tell him. Reaches into his pocket fo card.

Sorry, ma‘am. We have no legal basis to remove your husband from the house. (hands her the card) Next time you feel that things are getting out of control, you should call that number. That’s the family hotline. (CONTINUED)
BREAKING BAD #303 "I.F.T." Writer's Draft 8/26/09 18.

The Senior Officer motions across the room for his partne The Rookie Officer crosses to the front door to meet him. Walt follows to see the police out, while Skyler sits dow the couch, utterly humiliated.
Best of luck to you folks.
Thank you, Officers. The two cops head out. As soon as they leave, Walter, Jr. anger at Skyler explodes: WALTER, JR. How _c: that t ! Walter, Jr. storms off toward his room. Walt calls out:

Son, wait... Don’t blame your mother for this. But it falls on deaf ears. 0O.S., we hear his bedroom doo SLAM shut as he locks himself in. Skyler, seething in her defeat, walks up to Walt. Takes the baby from his arms.
(calm, but venomous) Welcome home. She, too, disappears down the hallway. SLAMS the door to bedroom. Off grim Walt, stewing in his “victory”...
BREAKING BAD #303 "I.F.T." Writer's Draft 8/26/09 19.

LOW and WIDE ON JESSE, knees to chest, sitting on the flo His back is propped against a newly-painted bare wall. We’re in the living room of Jesse’s big “new” house. No furniture yet. Nothing but a field of glossy hardwood flo in the f.g., bathed in a pale sunlight slipping through t window. Dwarfed by the wall, Jesse stares introspectively off into the empty space. A lonely tableau. Several moments pass, before he fishes a cell phone from pocket. Presses speed dial, puts the receiver to his ear. When the call goes through (we don’t hear it), a faint, nostalgic smile creases his face. It’s a sweet moment. A fleeting glimpse of the Jesse we knew before the plane cr the addiction, the loss. What did he just hear? DING-DONG, the doorbell rings. Jesse hangs up. But he doesn’t budge. He’s got no desire to see anyone. DING-DONG, again. Followed by a hard KNOCK-KNOCK! Jesse considers. Whoever it is knows he’s inside. He pockets th phone. Rises, paces slowly to the door. Opens, to find... SAUL, wearing a shit-eating grin. He holds a cheap, pathe looking POTTED CACTUS, the kind you get from Ralph's. Jes is not thrilled to see him (he’s been dodging Saul’s call
He lives! (off deadpan Jesse) Happy housewarming, kid. Don‘t look so glad to see me. Saul hands him the cactus. Oh, boy.

Cool. Thanks. Saul waits to be invited inside. Jesse would prefer not t but Saul did just help him fleece his parents for the cri Reluctantly, he steps aside. Saul files in, looks around empty space. Jesse sets the cactus down by the window sil
Interesting decor. Subtle. The whole minimalist thing never blew my hair back, but hey. (off Jesse) So. Howya doing? Staying clean? (CONTINUED )
BREAKING BAD #303 “I.F.T." Writer's Draft 8/26/09 20.
Jesse nods -- yeah.

Good. I was kinda worried you were back to your old habits, since I didn’t hear from you. You got any idea how stupid it is to ignore your counsel’s calls? (beat) What if I was tryin’ to warn you the DEA was about to kick in your door? What then, huh?
How’s about you spare me the sermon and get to why you're here?

(beat, resets) Fair enough. The other day, when I brought up the idea about you gettin’ back in touch with your partner. Well, I kinda wanna re- float that boat. (beat, Jesse is blank) Don’t get all excited. I'm not suggesting you yourself get back to cooking. You being in rehab and all, that would be... beyond the pale, even for me. (beat) I care about you, kid. I only want you to convince the master-chef to do his thing. So... Whaddya say? Jesse gets it. Unlike Walt, he’s not essential to Saul’s deal with Gus. In fact, Jesse's irrelevant. For any meth cook with a smidgen of pride, it’s a major snub. But Jess appears not to care. Even gives a half-hearted shrug:
Sure, man. Whatever. Jesse tries to show him to the door. But:
Whoa, whoa, hold on. ‘Whatever’ what? You gonna talk to him?
I said, I'll handle it. Now, bounce, will ya, please. (CONTINUED)
BREAKING BAD #303 "I.F.T." Writer's Draft 8/26/09 21.
Saul reads him. Still skeptical. But for now, he’s played his hand. Throws him the Saul finger point.

Final thought. (re: the empty house) Look at this place. You’re house poor, you got no bankroll. You get the maestro cooking again, I can make it worth your while. Call him. Saul leaves. Alone again, Jesse heads back to his perch a the wall. Sits, tries to clear his mind. But he can’t. He reaches for his cell again. Speed dials. This time, we hear what he was listening to before: JANE‘'S VOICEMAIL MESSAGE (established in Episode 213):

Hey. If you're trying to sell me something, I've got four little words for you: Do-Not-Call... The message CUTS OFF. Weird. Jesse waits a couple beats. Presses speed dial again. This time he gets that familiar three-tone sequence, followed by the operator recording:

The number you have reached: One- Four-Nine, Four-Nine-Eight-Five, in area code Five-Zero-Five, is no longer in service. If you feel you've reached this recording in error... Jesse hangs up. Until Skyler takes a few steps closer... and we see that
Skyler’s jaw drops. Before her, more cash than she’s ever seen in her life -- more than she ever imagined Walt had cooking meth. Though her expression is not one of greed o lust, she is astounded.

Skyler... She looks over to Walt, who stands nearby in the living r Gauging her every reaction. Partly because she’s entrance by the sight of so much cash -- but also because she now needs to hear how her once humble schoolteacher husband c lay claim to so much money -- she slowly steps over to th breakfast bar and takes a seat on the nearest stool. Her body language is clear. She is ready to listen.

Walt doesn't come too close to her, afraid it might unset her and cause her to leave. Keeping his distance, he lean against the back of the armchair in the living room (the money framed between them in the b.g.). When he begins to speak, he’s not the resigned Walt of yesterday. This Walt impassioned, sincere. Yet also nervous, for he knows that this is his one chance to make his case.

I did a terrible thing. An illegal thing. No one knows that better than I do. But I did it for a good reason. I did it for us. (re: the money) That right there... that’s not about money for my medical expenses. I grant you, I could've taken Gretchen’s handout to cover that. No. This is so much bigger than that. (beat) It’s for Walter, Jr.'s physical therapy, his SAT tutor. Money for groceries, and for gas, and for graduation parties. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

For Holly's day care while you go to work. Her braces when she's older. (beat) Skyler, that money is for this roof over your head -- the mortgage that you’re not going to be able to afford on a part time bookkeeper's salary when I’m gone.
